title: Banking & Finance: Ex-Goldman Partner Spells Out Scheme --- In trial of colleague in 1MDB case, Leissner says he conspired to bribe Malaysia officials
text:
But Mr. Leissner said he and Mr. Ng hid from Goldman the role of a Malaysian financier in the deal and a scheme to pay bribes to government officials in Malaysia and Abu Dhabi.

"I knew it was illegal," he said. "I wanted this to be done for Goldman Sachs. I wanted to be a hero at Goldman Sachs."

Mr. Leissner is the star witness for the prosecution in Mr. Ng's criminal trial.

Mr. Ng, a former Goldman managing director, and the financier, Jho Low, were charged in 2018 with conspiring to launder money and conspiring to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. Mr. Ng is the first criminal defendant in the U.S. case to face a jury.

Mr. Leissner, who is cooperating with the government, has pleaded guilty to U.S. charges of conspiracy to launder money and violate antibribery laws for his role in the scandal.

Mr. Leissner said Wednesday he and his family received between $50 million and $60 million in kickbacks as part of the scheme. Federal prosecutors have accused Mr. Ng of receiving $35 million in kickbacks.

Marc Agnifilo, a lawyer for Mr. Ng, said at the opening of the trial that his client was innocent and blamed Mr. Leissner, Mr. Ng's former boss, calling him an immoral man who was testifying in hope of getting a reduced sentence.

Goldmanpaid more than $5 billion in penalties to the U.S., and Malaysia and took away compensation from some top executives.

A spokeswoman for Goldman declined to comment.

Mr. Leissner testified that he and Mr. Ng were close friends at Goldman who spoke about business and their compensation in and outside of the office. Mr. Leissner said in 2008 he learned of Mr. Low, a young businessman who had powerful connections in Malaysia and the Middle East and was making a name for himself on billion-dollar deals. Mr. Ng, a Malaysian national whose work focused on drumming up business in the country, pursued a relationship with Mr. Low, according to Mr. Leissner. "At Goldman Sachs we were tasked with always finding new business opportunities," he said.

After Messrs. Ng and Low became close, the three began discussing deals, including the 1MDB bond offerings, according to Mr. Leissner.

Messrs. Ng and Leissner hid Mr. Low's involvement from Goldman because of his reputation, Mr. Leissner said. Mr. Low had previously been rejected as a Goldman client after compliance teams raised red flags about the source of his income, according to prosecutors.

Before the first bond offering, Messrs. Low, Leissner and Ng met in London, where Mr. Low sketched out on a piece of paper the officials in Malaysia and Abu Dhabi who needed to be bribed, Mr. Leissner said.

The list included former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, according to Mr. Leissner. Mr. Razak was later accused of embezzling more than $680 million from the 1MDB fund. He was sentenced in 2020 to 12 years imprisonment after a court in his country found him guilty of abuse of power.
